claim: Antarctica has a lot of problems relating to homelessness.

supporting.text: Antarctica has no permanent human population, making homelessness irrelevant as there are no residents to be homeless.

attacks.text: Antarctica has no permanent human population, making homelessness irrelevant as there are no residents to be homeless.
While there is no permanent population, seasonal researchers and support staff may face housing shortages or inadequate shelter.
Housing for seasonal workers is typically pre-arranged and strictly regulated, minimizing the risk of homelessness.
Homelessness can also refer to lack of stable or safe shelter, which could apply to temporary residents in extreme conditions.
Antarctic research stations are equipped with emergency protocols and backup shelters, reducing the likelihood of unsafe conditions.

supporting.text: The continent is primarily inhabited by researchers and support staff who live in controlled, temporary housing provided by scientific stations.

attacks.text: The continent is primarily inhabited by researchers and support staff who live in controlled, temporary housing provided by scientific stations.
Some individuals, such as undocumented workers or stranded tourists, may still experience homelessness in Antarctica due to lack of formal support systems.
Documented cases of homelessness in Antarctica are extremely rare and often quickly resolved by international cooperation among research stations.
The Antarctic Treaty System explicitly prohibits any permanent human settlement, making homelessness a structural impossibility.
Harsh environmental conditions make survival without organized support nearly impossible, effectively preventing homelessness.

supporting.text: Antarctica's extreme climate and lack of infrastructure make it uninhabitable for long-term human settlement, eliminating the possibility of homelessness.

attacks.text: Antarctica's extreme climate and lack of infrastructure make it uninhabitable for long-term human settlement, eliminating the possibility of homelessness.
Scientific research stations in Antarctica house personnel year-round, proving limited but stable human habitation is possible.
Research station residents are transient workers, not permanent settlers, so homelessness remains irrelevant to Antarctica's population.
Homelessness could theoretically occur if Antarctic research stations evicted personnel without return transport arrangements.
International Antarctic treaties require all personnel to have guaranteed evacuation plans, preventing abandonment scenarios.

supporting.text: International treaties, such as the Antarctic Treaty System, regulate human activity on the continent, ensuring that all presence is temporary and organized, preventing homelessness.

attacks.text: International treaties, such as the Antarctic Treaty System, regulate human activity on the continent, ensuring that all presence is temporary and organized, preventing homelessness.
Some research stations in Antarctica have reported cases of individuals overstaying their contracts or being stranded due to logistical failures, creating temporary homelessness.
The Antarctic Treaty System does not explicitly address the enforcement of temporary stays, leaving room for ambiguity in practice.
Stranded individuals are typically evacuated or reassigned quickly, minimizing any real homelessness.
